results.title: Pigeon that came home: a story of the Fjord country
results.brief_description: The life of Norwegian farm boys living by a fjord, enjoying swimming, fishing, boating and farming. They care for a pigeon “Lucky” and train her to carry messages. She plays her part in the exciting rescue when one of the boys has an accident. An introduction to Norway - its geography, people and customs.

results.title: Pig too far gone
results.brief_description: Chief Kosher is having a hard time busting open a crime ring and nabbing the King Pin, when the cops he sends undercover find it impossible to go unnoticed. His only option is to send in loose-cannon McBurger, which could be his best or worst decision to date.

results.title: Piet Mondriaan: un film essai
results.brief_description: By relating a careful selection of about fifty paintings and drawings, we trace Mondriaan’s development from naturalism through cubism to pure abstraction.

results.title: Pies (K)
results.creator_credit: Sheldon Cohen, Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Based on a short story by Canadian author Wilma Riley, this animation film is about ethnic prejudice in all its blind viciousness. Mrs. Cherwak is Polish and owns a cow. Mrs. Meuser is a German with entrenched notions of cleanliness. She does not appreciate the cow’s inevitable by-product. The film describes their conflict and its curious resolution over coffee and mincemeat pie. While the author chose to write about the Germans and the Poles she grew up with on the outskirts of Regina, the situation she describes could apply anywhere in the world. (Award: New York.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sheldon Cohen, Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Pierrot le Fou = Crazy Pete (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Ferdinand (aka Pierrot), dissatisfied with his Parisian life and his wife sets off to a picaresque journey across France to the South with Marianne. Along the way, they get involved with her brother and his criminal activities. Godard’s stunning study of personal and global violence uses colour in a dramatic and symbolic manner. In many ways it is a watershed film in which Godard calls his whole work in the cinema into question. It is also a summation of his work to this time, an unclassifiable film of disorientingly abrupt changes of mood combining the diary form with pulp fiction and romantic tragedy, experimentation in narration with filmed essay all heavily laden with cultural and political references. As American director Sam Fuller reflects in the picture, ‘Film is like a battleground, love, hate, action, violence, death … in one word, Emotion.’

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Anna Karina, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Dirk Sanders, Hans Meyer, Raymond Devos, Samuel Fuller.

results.title: Pierrot le Fou
results.brief_description: Pierrot escapes his boring society and travels from Paris to the Mediterranean Sea with Marianne, a girl chased by hit-men from Algeria. They lead an unorthodox life, always on the run in Jean-Luc Goddard’s 1965 French New Wave classic.

constellations_other.name: All about Agnes
constellations_other.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

constellations_other.name: Gunslingers, good fellas and flea bags
constellations_other.description: Explore how a 1903 western changed the course of filmmaking and videogames by breaking the fourth wall.

results.title: Pierre le Grand et son epoque = Pierre the Great and his times
results.brief_description:
Episode 19 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Peter the Great, czar of Russia (1672-1725) was one of this country’s greatest statesmen, organisers, and reformers. Major events of his reign are covered in this episode, including the war against Sweden, the construction of St Petersburg and Peter’s various attempts at modernising the country and opening it to Western ideas.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].
